title: Champion mastery should encourage playing new champions.
body:
Such as granting IP on crest rank-up, or giving a small IP boost when playing a champion with low level of mastery.

That will encourage people to think outside of the meta and reduce the amount of people who tryhard with their mains on normals.

It's a win-win situation.

replies.body:
I thought Mastery was used to reward those why are dedicated to a champion? Doesn't your idea completely change the entire point of the system?

Also, playing something other than your main is not playing outside the meta.

Given how many points you get per won game ( 800+ pts ) maxing a champion won't take too long. The idea rewards mastering a champion in general "Champion mastery" obviously you want to master as many as possible in the long run, therefore a completion reward is sensible for "dedication" while a small IP boost bonus when starting a new champion is incentive to keep scoring "Mastered" champions.

The larger your champion pool, the more comfortable you are playing a champion outside the norm no?

Riot has said they plan to introduce more levels after awhile. 
The point of this wasn't to make people play a bunch of of meta stuff. It was intended to help show those on your team that you are good at that person in that position even if it is outside the box.

While I don't disagree completely, I don't think you can really blame the angry mob for tossing rocks when you hand them more rocks to toss. There were and are ways to positively impact...multiple things, just with the mastery system I feel, but the way they implemented it wasn't it.

It is little more than a basic achievement system that decided to grade you based on an arbitrary set of data you aren't privy to, as another way for those people looking for reasons to judge people, to be judgemental. There are already third party websites to allow people to see your elo, the champs you play, the masteries you use, etc, and now someone in champ select can see my profile and see I don't have, say, Braum mastered and think I'm bad at it, mostly because the system isn't retroactive (but that is another issue entirely).

Sadly I've been around this community too long and I've become cynical :(

Outside the normal set of good champions is not breaking the meta. Simply means you have a larger champion pool. Every pro players says having a dedicated small roster of champions is more reliable than being okay with several champions. 

I may be wrong though about the system though. If the gains are that high you won't 'master' a champion, or come even close, upon getting max "Champion Mastery". Riot should have called it "Champion Basics Mastery."

The cycle of meta rolls round and round. I wouldn't say previous mastered champions would go forgotten, the system will probably work as a reminder of what you used to be good at when the meta favored that champ if you're a meta person.

I wouldn't.

Right now on your profile page and hover card for your friends, there is a combined Mastery Score that adds up all your Mastery levels across the champs you have levels on. We've also tuned the system to make Rank 5 fairly accessible (20-30 games-ish) so leveling the other champs you own is a little easier (well, unless you own all 120+ champs :p).

That said, agree there's probably more that we could be doing here to reward breadth, and not just depth, of the champions you play. This is definitely something we're looking into for future updates.

You could add an Icon for mastering a champion in every role, it could be a "Jax of all trades" icon, or an icon for mastering multiple champions in a specific role, like a guardian icon for mastering multiple supports.

Some champ specific icons would be cool too, Like a "Charming" icon for mastering Ahri for example.

A good, but ~minor~, thing you could do is reward based on champion mastery * champions mastered. Example:

I just hit rank 5 on Jinx! YAY! OH look, it says you have mastered one champion here is ~100 ip~.
I then hit rank 5 on Ashe! YAY THATS 2! Oh look, 200 ip!!!!

Etcetra etcetra. Each time you hit rank 5, you gain 100 IP*number_of_champions_at_rank_5.  Something like that maybe? Or perhaps an icon of each like we have on this page? Or reward per rank? Idk.

1. Riot intentionally isn't telling us the scoring system so that we keep playing to win, not to farm mastery xp. If they tell us cs is all that really matters, you can bet your old grannie's dentures I'm gonna be going top and hard farming all game every game. That would ruin a lot of games for everyone.

2. It's relative to other people playing the same champion at your elo. So for example, if all Bronze Lee Sins suck but yours sucks the least, you can do poorly and still earn full points for your win/loss. Which means every role as a whole gets a fair share of mastery xp. If dragon count is an important thing for junglers, maybe you'll finally start buying a couple wards for dragon control. Might not be perfect but still a good thing overall.

3. Everyone wins and loses around 50/50 so putting more of the points into wins accounts for all the invisible factors like chat attitude that aren't tracked by hard data. It doesn't really affect your overall point distribution unless you're one of those bronze players who gets really fed on good mechanics but doesn't cooperate with the team and ends up losing anyways. So you earn high grades but still lose a lot.

4. Finally, you can at least be sure that 0-15-2 Singed in your game really has played at least 30 games with him and is just terrible at league, not a liar.

As support, I've noticed that the more time I spend in jg, the lower my grade is.  Which is weird because warding is good.  Also, when the transition from laning to team-fighting is long and ugly, you spend a lot of time running between bot and mid.

And bouncing between lanes isn't an obviously wrong choice to me.  You can't just leave bot wide open and sit in mid waiting for the other team's next push attempt.  3 people sitting mid soaking xp from the laner isn't helping anyone, especially when bot needs winions cleared out.

I think that there are enough glaring problems with the system for people to not take it seriously as a skill metric.  For example, I went YOLO Cassio top last night against a Sion and lost my lane pretty hard.  I over-pushed lane WAY too far and too early trying to build passive stacks, so to farm anything I had to be extremely over-extended. A roaming fed Sion was probably the biggest contributor to the loss.  In other words, I single-handedly lost us the game since our other laners had good advantage until Sion showed up.

But I ended up with the highest score on the team.  It was a B or B+ when it should have been a D.  It's just all based on weird metrics that don't account for true impact on a game.  Another example was a game where I was basically a meat shield support, and we ended up with a super-fed ADC while the other team had a fed turret.  I got a C that game, even though 3 or 4 of my deaths were executes that gave our ADC a kill.
